results.title: Dangerous game
results.creator_credit: Quantum Films, Virgo Productions, Judith West, Basil Appleby and Stephen Hopkins
results.brief_description: Dangerous game is director Stephen Hopkins’ debut feature film but he is better known for his later features “Nightmare on Elm Street 5”, “Predator 2”, “Lost in space”, “Blown away” and several TV productions, including “24”. This Australian thriller, set in Sydney, centres around a group of five uni students, David (Miles Buchanan), Jack (Marcus Graham), Tony (John Polson), Kathryn (Kathryn Walker) and Ziggy (Sandie Lillingston) whose lives are suddenly turned upside down when they decide on a whim, late one night, to break into a department store - just for the sheer thrill of it all. What they were unprepared for, however, was the presence of Murphy (Steven Grives) the psycho cop who had, for reasons of his own, taken to stalking and harrassing Jack, pursuing him in a menacing, almost fanatical, manner to such a point that he lost his job that very day through Jack reporting him. Now Murphy is the security guard in the department store and he wants revenge. From a fairly slow start, the film gradually builds up into an action thriller with some tense moments and unexpected outcomes. Based on an original script by Michael Ralph, screenplay by Peter West and cinematography by Peter Levy.

results.title: Dangerous creatures (PC)
results.brief_description: Welcome to the interactive world of dangerous creatures! You’ll be amazed as you discover the truth - and the extraordinary myths - about these intriguing creatures. ‘Dangerous creatures’ comes with an overview movie that teaches you the basics of using the program. The first time you start the program, you’ll be given the opportunity to see the overview. You can also choose to see the overview whenever you like. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Multimedia PC that includes a 386SX or higher, at least 4MB of RAM, 2.5MB of available hard disk space, CD-ROM drive, audio board and VGA or VGA+. MS DOS and Microsoft Windows operating system version 3.1 or later.

results.title: Dangerous charter
results.creator_credit: Gold Key Entertainment, Robert Gottschalk and John Moore
results.brief_description: Three bluefin fishermen going about their daily routine find a luxury yacht, ‘Medusa’ drifting on the sea and decide to board her. Finding a dead body and no one else there, shipmates Marty, Kick and Joe see dollar signs appearing before their eyes and agree to salvage it. On dry land the F.B.I and coast guard are intrigued by the mysterious vessel. Marty and co. are allowed to keep the yacht on one condition- that they are used as fish bait to catch the owner of the vessel, a man believed to be a wealthy criminal involved in narcotics. The bait is taken and the drama begins. With corny humour and some bad acting, one could think the film may not stay afloat, however the well paced story line seems to keep the movie moving along enjoyably. Cast includes Chris Warfield, Sally Fraser and Richard Foote.

results.title: Danger! Radio active waste
results.creator_credit: Films Incorporated, NBC News and Joan Konner
results.brief_description: Progress is in a dead heat with destruction as the nuclear industry tries to keep ahead of its own waste, all of which is radioactive and therefore highly dangerous. The horrors of radioactive overexposure - possible genetic damage, increased incidences of cancer and leukemia, and others, are further heightened by an apparent inability of both government and industry to solve the nuclear waste disposal problem.

results.title: Danger level
results.creator_credit: Christopher Productions, Ansvar Insurance and Warren J Mills
results.brief_description: Tests of the effects of alcohol consumption on driving performance carried out by the Univeristy of New South Wales at the Warwick Farm Motor Racing Circuit. Volunteers including leading professional drivers undertake tests of skill after dosage to various blood alcohol levels, showing how ability is impaired.

results.title: Dandy dust (E)
results.brief_description: This genre-defying, gender-bending, no-budget, experimental feature draws its inspiration from such diverse sources as cyberpunk, anime, splatter films, sci-fi, Hong Kong action flicks, feminist theory, and queer underground cinema. Dandy is a “cyborg techno-human of fluid gender” who participates in a series of surreal, fetishistic sexual encounters whilst travelling across time and space in a bizzare futuristic universe. Extreme, visceral and visually inventive, the film gleefully upturns conventional notions of narrative, sex, gender and family, in its irreverent exploration of the relationship between body and machine, and the interplay between violence, eroticism and ritual. Cast includes Tre Temperilli, Hans Schierl and Svar Simpson.

results.title: Dandenong South Public Art Project
results.creator_credit: Mal Padgett, Michael Blunden and Renata Slusarski
results.brief_description: In 2004 a collaboration between the City of Greater Dandenong, Big Fish (a design and construction team), and the community of Dandenong South was formed to create a permanent, highly visible sculpture representing the cultural diversity of Dandenong South. Children from the Dandenong South Primary School were given disposable cameras and asked to take photos of the things that were culturally important to them and their favourite places in Dandenong South. Conversations with the local school children, community leaders, local identities and workers in Dandenong South were recorded on film and it was from both the children’s images and the different perspectives captured in the film that ultimately combined to provide the inspiration and design for the artists’ symbolic community artwork.

results.title: Dancing orpheus
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and K Porteous
results.brief_description: The unique Australian lyrebird, this most elusive of all birds, is observed in its natural habitat. A long sequence, excellently photographed and brilliantly recorded sound, shows the bird performing its famous courting dance. The long hours of patient photography involved have been rewarded with the following awards - Australian Film Awards, Nature Section, Gold Award “for nature shots, lyrically observed and creatively connected.” Kodak Silver Medallion for best black and white photography.
